NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year of the Government ends on 31 December. 
 
(ii)  In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by a team consisting of J. Zveglich (team leader), Operations 
Coordination Division; S. Handayani, Social Sectors Division, East and Central Asia 
Department; and R. Abbasov, Azerbaijan Resident Mission.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Azerbaijan requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) technical 
assistance (TA) for the support of the formulation of its new national poverty reduction strategy. 
In  considering  this  request,  ADB  developed  a  concept  paper,  in  consultation  with  the 
Government, and this paper was endorsed by a peer review for funding from the Cooperation 
Fund in Support of the Formulation of National Poverty Reduction Strategies (NPRS Fund) on 
17 November 2004. ADB fielded a fact-finding mission to Azerbaijan on 17–26 January 2005. 
This mission reached an understanding with the Government on the goals, purpose, scope, 
implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for the TA.1 
The design and monitoring framework is presented in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Azerbaijan enjoyed strong growth and a stable macroeconomic environment in recent 
years.  Since  2000,  growth  in  real  gross  domestic  product  averaged  10.6%  per  year,  with 
inflation at a moderate 3.0% annually. The Government maintained prudent fiscal policy, and its 
monetary policy supported low inflation rates. However, this strong growth performance masks 
a considerable poverty problem in the country. According to the 2002 household budget survey, 
46.7% of the population lives in poverty.2 Much of the recent growth and immediate growth 
prospects come from the development of the oil and gas sector. The country is now shifting 
from a situation where growth was driven by oil-sector investments to one in which growth will 
be driven by oil-sector production. A key issue for the country is how to ensure that the benefits 
of the country’s growth reach all segments of society. 
 
3.  From July 2001 to October 2002, the Government prepared its strategy for poverty 
reduction,  which  was  entitled  the  State  Programme  on  Poverty  Reduction  and  Economic 
Development (SPPRED) 2003–2005. The Ministry of Economic Development (MOED), through 
the SPPRED Secretariat, led the development of the strategy and the broad public consultations 
that supported this process. ADB provided TA to support the preparation of the strategy and 
strengthen the capacity of the SPPRED Secretariat to guide the strategy’s implementation.3 The 
boards of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank endorsed SPPRED 2003–2005 
as the country’s poverty reduction strategy paper. ADB also endorsed the strategy, basing its 
country strategy and program updates on this document. 
 
4.  As  the  implementation  period  for  SPPRED  2003–2005  comes  to  a  close,  the 
Government announced its intention to develop its follow-on poverty reduction plan. The new 
strategy will be a 10-year strategy centered on the achievement of the Millennium Development 
Goals  (MDG).  The  Government  will  take  advantage  of  the  capacity  for  developing  and 
implementing  poverty  reduction  plans  within  the  SPPRED  Secretariat,  as  the  Government 
embarks on the formulation of the MDG strategy. Under SPPRED 2003–2005, the SPPRED 
Secretariat was responsible for (i) coordinating the efforts of government agencies and funding 
organizations in ensuring successful implementation of the policy actions set out in the national

2   
strategy, (ii) improving government capacity to define and monitor key poverty indicators, (iii) 
taking the participatory process forward and developing further the dialogue between policy 
makers and civil society, (iv) monitoring the implementation of the policy measures set out in the 
national strategy and reviewing them on an annual basis, and (v) ensuring that macroeconomic 
and fiscal policies are consistent and support the strategy set out in the document. 
 
5.  While much was accomplished during the implementation of SPPRED, further capacity 
building will enhance the effectiveness of the Government’s poverty reduction efforts under the 
new strategy. In particular, the participatory processes should be refined and expanded to better 
reflect the priorities of the local communities in the national strategy and provide better feedback 
on the poverty impacts of the Government’s efforts. Moreover, the links between MOED and the 
SPPRED  Secretariat  (the  planning  and  monitoring  arm  of  the  Government)  and  the  line 
ministries responsible for executing the public investment plan need to be strengthened. Finally, 
the strategy’s targets need to be fully costed and integrated into the medium-term expenditure 
framework and public investment program and reflected in the annual fiscal budgets, if the 
strategy is to be credible. 
 
6.  During the development and implementation of SPPRED 2003–2005, ADB coordinated 
closely with the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and the World Bank, as the 
three agencies all provided TA to the SPPRED Secretariat. In general, ADB TA supported 
strategy  implementation,  while  UNDP  TA  supported  poverty  monitoring  and  World  Bank 
assistance helped strengthen the links to the fiscal budget. That close cooperation will continue 
under this TA. UNDP already began additional assistance to the Government to develop the 
MDG strategy, and the scope of work and terms of reference for this TA were discussed with 
UNDP, to avoid overlap. 
 
7.  ADB is preparing the first full country strategy and program (CSP) for Azerbaijan. By 
providing technical support for the formulation of the national poverty reduction strategy, ADB 
can better harmonize its assistance program with the country’s development priorities. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA will assist the Government in integrating the achievement of the MDG into its 
development planning and implementation processes. The main outcome will be the enhanced 
planning and monitoring capacity of MOED to achieve those goals. The main deliverables of the 
TA are (i) an evaluation of SPPRED 2003–2005, emphasizing lessons learned, to aid in the 
preparation of the country’s next phase of its poverty reduction strategy; (ii) an integrated 
training program to improve the planning capacity of the interministerial sector working groups 
and link their work to the national strategy; (iii) a strategy for achieving the country’s MDG 
targets,  with  a  fully  costed  investment  plan;  and  (iv)  the  procedures  and  processes  for 
monitoring strategy implementation, updating the strategy based on implementation experience, 
monitoring budgetary flows and revising the costing, and disseminating information on the 
progress in achieving the goals. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will build on the practices and institutional structures established during the 
SPPRED 2003–2005 process. The scope of work will include (i) an evaluation of SPPRED 
2003–2005 and (ii) support for MDG strategy formulation and implementation.

3
1.  Evaluation of the State Programme on Poverty Reduction and Economic 
Development 2003–2005 
 
10.  The  evaluation  of  the  SPPRED  2003–2005  component  will  be  a  key  input  for  the 
formulation of the MDG strategy and ADB’s CSP. This component will prepare an evaluation 
study of processes used to develop and implement SPPRED, institutions involved, and systems 
established for monitoring and evaluating impacts of the strategy. The evaluation will include 
discussions in the regions with community groups involved in earlier consultations, to gauge 
their impressions of the effectiveness of the participatory aspects of SPPRED. The study will 
emphasize lessons learned, so as to inform all involved of the development and implementation 
of the MDG strategy. Related to the evaluation work, this component will include the preparation 
of the country poverty assessment, which is a key background study for the CSP that provides a 
comprehensive examination of the constraints to and opportunities for poverty reduction in the 
country, so as to better align ADB’s assistance. 
  
  2.  Millennium Development Goals Strategy Formulation and Implementation 
 
11.  The  MDG  strategy  formulation  and  implementation  component  will  support  the 
Government’s efforts to develop a fully costed strategy for achieving the MDG, including targets 
and baseline indicators appropriate for Azerbaijan’s current state of development. The MDG 
strategy and its annual progress reports and updates will be produced in a participatory manner, 
through a series of regional meetings. The strategy documents and annual updates will be 
discussed  in  an  annual  workshop  by  a  wide  range  of  stakeholders,  including  government 
agencies  and  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  and  private  sector  organizations  and 
development partner community members. This component will also facilitate the meetings of 
the interministerial sector working groups that were established as part of the SPPRED process, 
to provide an important feedback mechanism to the SPPRED Secretariat from the technical 
experts within government on the feasibility of the strategy and implementation progress. 
 
12.  The TA will strengthen the strategy implementation and impact monitoring mechanisms 
put in place under SPPRED 2003–2005, enhancing the capacity of the SPPRED Secretariat to 
carry out participatory poverty impact monitoring of projects and policy measures identified in 
the strategy. This component will also engage the services of two local NGOs, to enhance the 
scope of participatory monitoring of the strategy during implementation. The TA will also advise 
all involved on the inclusion of qualitative poverty indicators in the MDG monitoring system, in 
consultation with the SPPRED poverty monitoring unit, including setting appropriate baselines. 
 
13.  The MDG costing and budgeting exercise will support the development of feasible MDG 
targets, by making explicit the financial implications of these targets. The TA will prepare cost 
estimates of the investments and policy reforms needed to achieve the strategic targets, given 
the baseline levels of the agreed indicators. The TA will also provide analytical support to the 
fiscal  budgeting  process,  to  ensure  that  the  medium-term  expenditure  framework,  public 
investment plan, and annual fiscal budgets are consistent with MDG strategy costing. The TA 
will also monitor the execution of the fiscal budget, to highlight any shifts in spending patterns 
inconsistent with the achievement of the MDG targets and prescribe early corrective actions. 
 
14.  The TA will provide assistance for capacity building and information dissemination and 
prepare a training-needs assessment that will be based on previous needs assessments within 
the  SPPRED  Secretariat  and  take  into  account  training  already  completed.  From  this 
assessment, the TA will develop a training program and deliver training courses to strengthen 
the capacity of the sector working groups to implement the MDG strategy. The TA will also

4   
prepare and execute a public information plan, contracting a local public relations and media 
advisory services firm for this purpose. The plan will use various media to notify the public about 
the MDG strategy formulation process and disseminate strategy implementation results. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,070,000 equivalent, comprising $592,000 in 
foreign exchange and $478,000 equivalent in local currency. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by the NPRS Fund and by ADB's TA funding program. The NPRS Fund will provide 
$650,000 equivalent, comprising $432,000 in foreign exchange and $218,000 equivalent in local 
currency. ADB will provide $200,000 equivalent, comprising $160,000 in foreign exchange and 
$40,000 equivalent in local currency. The Government will finance the remaining $220,000 
equivalent of the local currency costs, covering in-kind support, such as office facilities and 
administrative support and staff time. Appendix 2 shows the cost estimates and financing plan. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The SPPRED Secretariat within MOED will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The 
consultants will work closely with the head of the SPPRED Secretariat. The Government will 
establish an advisory board, with representatives from the relevant line ministries and the main 
development partner agencies involved in the formulation and implementation of the MDG 
strategy.  The  Government  will  also  form  a  small  development  partner  coordination  group 
consisting of ADB, UNDP, and World Bank. The TA will be implemented over the 24-month 
period covering the formulation of the MDG strategy and the first year of implementation. The 
consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  the  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants by Asian Development Bank and Its Borrowers and other arrangements satisfactory 
to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. The outline terms of reference are given in 
Appendix 3. 
 
17.  For the evaluation of SPPRED 2003–2005, ADB will recruit on an individual basis an 
international  strategy  evaluation  specialist  for  2  person-months  and  a  domestic  poverty 
reduction specialist for 3 person-months. The consultants under this component will support the 
preparation of the CSP by drafting the country poverty assessment. 
 
18.  For the services in support of MDG strategy formulation and implementation, the scope 
of work will cover (i) MDG strategy development; (ii) MDG strategy implementation monitoring, 
strategy updating, and information dissemination; and (iii) MDG-related training program design 
and execution. In terms of international experts, ADB will engage an economist and team 
leader, a participatory monitoring and training specialist, and an economist and public finance 
specialist for a total of 15 person-months. For the services of the international experts, a 
consulting firm will be recruited using quality- and cost-based selection, with short-listed firms 
submitting simplified technical proposals. The consultants will engage the two local NGOs using 
direct selection, based on criteria acceptable to ADB. The consultants will contract the services 
of a domestic public relations and media advisory services firm, following the provisions of 
ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. As the estimated value of the contract is below $100,000 
equivalent, direct purchase may be used. 
 
19.  For the domestic experts, ADB will recruit a participatory implementation and monitoring 
specialist, a human capital development specialist, a regional development specialist, a gender 
and development specialist, and two public finance specialists for a total of about 96 person-
months.  The  domestic  consultants  will  be  engaged  on  an  individual  basis  by  ADB,  in

5
cooperation with the head of the SPPRED Secretariat. Direct selection will be used, where 
applicable,  for  consultants  engaged  under  existing  TA  arrangements  with  the  SPPRED 
Secretariat, to provide continuity. The head of the SPPRED Secretariat will supervise the day-
to-day work of the domestic experts, and the team leader will coordinate their work with the 
inputs of the international experts. 
 
20.  The main report under the services for the evaluation of SPPRED 2003–2005 is the 
evaluation  study.  A  draft  evaluation  report  will  be  submitted  by  the  seventh  week  of  the 
international evaluation specialist’s term of service. The report will be circulated to government 
agencies, ADB, and other development partners that were involved in the SPPRED 2003–2005 
process,  for  their  review.  The  international  evaluation  specialist  will  revise  the  report,  as 
necessary, and submit the final report at the end of the assignment in October 2005. The 
consultant will submit three print copies and one electronic copy of the report in English to ADB 
and three print copies and one electronic copy in Azeri to the head of the SPPRED Secretariat. 
The preliminary country poverty assessment will be submitted to ADB by October 2005 as well. 
 
21.  The main reports under the services for the formulation and implementation of the MDG 
strategy are the following: (i) inception report to be submitted 2 weeks after the commencement 
of the services of the team leader; (ii) quarterly TA implementation status reports, quarterly 
training  reports,  and  quarterly  public  information  reports;  (iii)  special  reports  prepared  in 
advance of TA review missions or following the completion of key activities (e.g., reports on 
national workshops and town hall meetings); and (iv) draft final and final reports. For the MDG 
strategy  costing  and  budgeting  exercise,  the  consultants  will  submit  (i)  full  costing  of  the 
investments needed to achieve the MDG targets, given the baselines for the agreed indicators 
(submitted by December 2005); (ii) annual analytical reports of the fiscal budget (final drafts in 
December 2005 and 2006); and (iii) quarterly reports monitoring the execution of the fiscal 
budget (submitted 2 months after the end of each fiscal quarter, beginning with the 2006 fiscal 
year). The consultants will submit three print copies and one electronic copy of all reports in 
English to ADB and three print copies and one electronic copy of all reports in Azeri to the head 
of the SPPRED Secretariat. 
 
22.  Results under the TA will be disseminated through three direct channels. First, the town 
hall meetings held during the design and implementation of the MDG strategy will provide an 
interactive forum for informing civil society in the regions. Second, the annual strategy review 
workshops will be used to inform representatives from  government agencies, civil society, 
business organizations, and the development partner community. Finally, the TA includes a 
public information component that will develop a variety of information dissemination vehicles, 
possibly including print, internet, and video, geared to reach a variety of audiences. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Cooperation Fund in Support of the Formulation of National 
Poverty Reduction Strategies, and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent 
of  $200,000  on  a  grant  basis  to  the  Government  of  Azerbaijan  for  Participatory  Strategy 
Development and Implementation for Achieving the Millennium Development Goals, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Evaluation of State Programme on Poverty Reduction and Economic Development 
2003–2005 
 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  recruit  a  strategy  evaluation  specialist 
(international, 2 person-months, intermittently over 3 months) and a poverty reduction specialist 
(domestic,  3  person-months).  The  international  consultant  will  be  an  economist  who  has 
extensive experience in strategy evaluation and a strong background in the development or 
evaluation of national poverty reduction strategies and experience working in Central Asia or the 
Caucuses. The domestic consultant will have expertise in poverty analysis and the use of 
participatory methods. The team of consultants will do the following: 
 
(i)  review  documentation  on  the  State  Programme  on  Poverty  Reduction  and 
Economic Development (SPPRED) 2003–2005 and the fiscal budgets supporting 
it and identify key issues in relation to the quality of the strategy and the extent to 
which the strategy was translated into an effective operational program by the 
Government; 
 
(ii)  prepare  an  inventory  of  all  participatory  activities  and  processes  during  the 
formulation of SPPRED 2003–2005 and interview a sample of the groups and 
individuals involved in the participatory processes on their roles in developing or 
implementing the SPPRED strategy and their perceptions of the effectiveness of 
their participation; 
 
(iii)  identify  key  issues  in  relation  to  the  quality  of  the  strategy  formulation  and 
implementation processes, especially their effectiveness in developing the final 
strategy document and translating it into specific actions, and enumerate the 
strengths  and  weaknesses  of  the  processes,  to  inform  all  involved  of  the 
development, implementation, and monitoring of the Millennium Development 
Goals (MDG) strategy; 
 
(iv)  assess  the  effectiveness  of  the  systems  established  for  monitoring  and 
evaluating the inputs and impacts of SPPRED 2003–2005; 
 
(v)  interview members of the SPPRED Secretariat, sector working groups, other 
local stakeholders (including development partners and international financial 
institutions)  on  their  roles  in  the  process  of  developing  and  implementing 
SPPRED 2003–2005 and their perceptions of the effectiveness of the processes; 
and 
 
(vi)  prepare  a  draft  evaluation  report;  highlight  any  institutional  constraints  that 
impinged on the development or implementation of the strategy; discuss the draft 
report  with  key  stakeholders  in  government  and  members  of  development 
partner  agencies  and  international  financial  institutions;  and  finalize  the 
evaluation report, taking into account the issues raised during these discussions. 
 
2.  As a complementary activity within the review of SPPRED 2003–2005, the consultants 
will draft a preliminary country poverty assessment to support the preparation of ADB’s country 
The consultants will prepare the outline of the country poverty assessment, in consultation with

Appendix 3  11 
ADB’s  country  team  leader  and  poverty  reduction  specialist,  and  prepare  the  background 
analysis on the poverty situation in the country. 
 
B.  Millennium Development Goals Strategy Formulation and Implementation 
 
3.  ADB will recruit an economist (international, 6.5 person-months, intermittently over 22.0 
months) to lead the team of experts in support of the formulation and implementation of the 
MDG strategy. The team will consist of a participatory poverty monitoring and training specialist 
(international, 3.0 person-months, intermittently over 6.0 months); an economist and public 
finance  specialist  (international,  5.5  person-months,  intermittently  over  18.0  months);  a 
participatory  implementation  and  monitoring  specialist  (domestic,  18.0  person-months);  a 
human capital development specialist (domestic, 18.0 person-months); a regional development 
specialist (domestic, 18.0 person-months); a gender and development specialist (domestic, 6.0 
person-months, intermittently over 12.0 months); and two public finance specialists (domestic, 
18.0 person-months each). In addition, the consultants will engage two local nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs) for local-level participatory monitoring of the implementation of the MDG 
strategy  and  contract  a  public  relations  and  media  advisory  services  firm  to  develop  and 
execute a public information program.  
 
1.  Economist 
 
4.  The international consultant engaged as the economist and team leader will (i) provide 
general support and management oversight to ensure delivery of the outputs of the consultants 
engaged under the technical assistance (TA), including the team for MDG strategy costing and 
budgeting but not the team evaluating SPPRED 2003–2005, in close coordination with the head 
of the SPPRED Secretariat and the chief technical adviser to the SPPRED Secretariat, and (ii) 
be the main point of contact with ADB’s project officer managing the TA on all administrative 
matters. The specific tasks of the economist and team leader are as follows: 
 
(i)  provide technical support for formulating and implementing the 10-year strategy 
for the achievement of the MDG and technical support for preparing the final 
SPPRED 2003–2005 progress report; 
 
(ii)  work with the consultants leading the MDG strategy costing and budgeting to 
ensure compatibility between the actions required under the MDG strategy and 
the medium-term expenditure framework, public investment plan, and annual 
fiscal budget; 
 
(iii)  oversee the training program, ensuring that the plan is up-to-date, to maximize its 
relevance  to  the  process  and  oversee  the  preparation  of  quarterly  training 
reports, in a form suitable to the head of the SPPRED Secretariat and ADB, and 
identify sources of funding for training activities; 
 
(iv)  engage a local public relations and media advisory services firm, in consultation 
with the head of the SPPRED Secretariat and ADB; oversee the work of the firm 
in the development, implementation, and updating of the public information plan 
and ensure the submission of quarterly public information reports acceptable to 
the head of the SPPRED Secretariat and ADB; and identify sources of funding 
for public relations and information dissemination activities; 
 
(v)  oversee the work of the two NGOs engaged for participatory monitoring;

12  Appendix 3 
 
(vi)  oversee the organization of (a) three national workshops (to discuss the final 
review of SPPRED 2003–2005, the draft of the 10-year MDG strategy, and the 
first review of the MDG strategy) and (b) six town hall meetings and oversee the 
preparation of the reports from these workshops and meetings; and 
 
(vii)  provide assistance to ADB, as necessary, to prepare the country strategy and 
program including finalizing the country poverty assessment. 
 
2.  Participatory Poverty Monitoring and Training Specialist 
 
5.  The international consultant engaged as the participatory poverty monitoring and training 
specialist will carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  review the participatory methods used under SPPRED 2003–2005, develop a 
plan  for  the  participation  in  the  formulation  and  implementation  of  the  MDG 
strategy,  and  create  a  specific  plan  for  increasing  the  access  of  previously 
underrepresented groups; 
 
(ii)  design  mechanisms  and  methods  for  participatory  processes,  establish 
institutional  arrangements,  prepare  cost  estimates,  and  develop  a  realistic 
timeline for coordinating participatory processes in the SPPRED Secretariat; 
 
(iii)  engage two local NGOs in consultation with the head of the SPPRED Secretariat 
and ADB and support the team leader in overseeing the work of these NGOs in 
the participatory monitoring of projects and policy measures identified in the 
strategy; 
 
(iv)  develop feedback mechanisms and participatory monitoring systems that enable 
civil society to help monitor, in cooperation with government officials, the main 
poverty reduction initiatives of the MDG strategy; 
 
(v)  develop  the  capacity  of  the  SPPRED  Secretariat,  especially  the  poverty 
monitoring  unit,  to  monitor  the  impact  of  strategy  implementation  on  the 
qualitative aspects of poverty and assist the SPPRED Secretariat in developing a 
set of qualitative MDG indicators, including their baselines, and integrate these 
into the MDG monitoring system; 
  
(vi)  review and update the training needs assessment and, based on the needs 
assessment, develop and execute a training program to strengthen the capacity 
of the sector working groups to formulate and implement the MDG strategy; and 
 
(vii)  strengthen the capacity of the SPPRED Secretariat to identify, develop, and 
deliver relevant training programs to the sector working groups, including training 
of trainers programs, as necessary; oversee initial training programs run by the 
SPPRED  Secretariat  and  provide  feedback;  develop  a  training  program  on 
participatory  monitoring  and  evaluation;  and  deliver  the  training  course  to 
SPPRED Secretariat domestic experts, members of the sector working groups, 
and the two NGOs engaged by the TA.

Appendix 3  13 
3.  Participatory Implementation and Monitoring Specialist 
 
6.  The domestic consultant engaged as the participatory implementation and monitoring 
specialist will carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  assist  in  the  institutional  strengthening  and  capacity  building  of  the  sector 
working groups and assist with the development of the monitoring and evaluation 
indicators by sector; 
 
(ii)  assist with the organization of workshops, town hall meetings, and stakeholder 
meetings and local consultations and assist the SPPRED Secretariat in preparing 
the final progress report of SPPRED 2003–2005, the 10-year MDG strategy 
document, and the first review of the MDG strategy; 
 
(iii)  assist the international participatory poverty monitoring and training specialist in 
(a) preparing reports on the participatory monitoring process; (b) reviewing and 
updating the training needs assessment, preparing the training program and 
quarterly training reports, and facilitating the training programs for the sector 
working groups; and (c) engaging the two NGOs for participatory monitoring and 
evaluation and liaising with the selected NGOs during the implementation of the 
participatory program; and 
 
(iv)  liaise with the public relations and media advisory services firm engaged under 
the  TA  regarding  the  public  information  program  and  its  implementation, 
including providing assistance in preparing specific public information materials 
and media events. 
 
4.  Human Capital Development Specialist 
 
7.  The domestic consultant engaged as the human capital development specialist will 
serve  as  the  focal  point  within  the  SPPRED  Secretariat  for  coordination  with  government 
agencies and sector working groups involved in human capital development, including the 
ministries of education, health, labor, and social protection; State Committee for Refugees and 
Internally Displaced Persons; and State Committee for Women’s Issues. The consultant will 
assist the sector working groups associated with these ministerial portfolios and government 
committees to devise monitoring and evaluation indicators for their sectors and help integrate 
these indicators into the MDG monitoring system. The consultant will also provide inputs to the 
budgeting team regarding the budget needed to achieve the sector-specific targets identified by 
the sector working groups. The consultant will provide inputs on the training needs of the sector 
working groups; assist with the preparation of all reports; and provide other support to the team 
leader, as necessary. 
 
5.  Regional Development Specialist 
 
8.  The domestic consultant engaged as the regional development specialist will serve as 
the focal point within the SPPRED Secretariat for coordination with government agencies and 
sector working groups involved in regional development, including the Investment Promotion 
and Advisory Fund; ministries of economic development; finance; fuel, energy and industry; and 
transportation; and Permanent Commission on Regional Issues. The consultant will assist the 
sector working groups associated with these ministerial portfolios and government committees 
to  devise  monitoring  and  evaluation  indicators  for  their  sectors  and  help  integrate  these

14  Appendix 3 
indicators  into  the  MDG  monitoring  system.  The  consultant  will  also  provide  inputs  to  the 
budgeting team regarding the budget needed to achieve the sector-specific targets identified by 
the sector working groups. The consultant will provide inputs on the training needs of the sector 
working groups; assist with the preparation of all reports; and provide other support to the team 
leader, as necessary. 
 
6.  Gender and Development Specialist 
 
9.  The domestic consultant engaged as the gender and development specialist will work 
with the participatory poverty monitoring and training specialist to conduct participatory gender 
assessments in the sector working groups, to identify the areas that will have the greatest 
strategic importance for promoting gender and development. The consultant will prepare a 
gender action plan for the MDG strategy, in collaboration with the sector working groups, and 
support the integration of gender indicators into the MDG monitoring system. Working with the 
participatory poverty monitoring and training specialist, the consultant will conduct training on 
gender and development for key stakeholder groups. Finally, the consultant will conduct a 
gender impact assessment of SPPRED 2003–2005, to be incorporated into the final progress 
report of SPPRED. 
 
  7.  Public Finance Team 
 
10.  Within the overall consultancy, the public finance team consists of the international 
economist and public finance specialist and the two domestic public finance specialists. The 
international consultant will be an economist with experience in public sector budgeting and 
costing of public programs. The domestic consultants will have backgrounds in finance and 
accounting, with an emphasis on public sector budgeting. The public finance team will do the 
following: 
 
(i)  assist  the  SPPRED  Secretariat  and  the  sector  working  groups  to  develop 
feasible targets for the country-specific MDG, given the baselines for the selected 
indicators and the investment cost needed to achieve those objectives; prepare a 
full costing of the investments needed to fulfill the targeted outcomes, given in 
the MDG strategy policy matrix; and review the cost estimates and revise as 
necessary over the course of strategy implementation; 
 
(ii)  prepare a global year-to-year cash budget for the MDG strategy policy matrix, 
identifying sources and uses of funds and any gaps, and coordinate with the 
Center of Economic Reforms in the Ministry of Economic Development and the 
Ministry of Finance to ensure compatibility between the actions required under 
the  MDG  strategy  and  the  medium-term  expenditure  framework,  public 
investment plan, and annual fiscal budget; and 
 
(iii)  monitor  the  execution  of  the  annual  fiscal  budget,  with  a  focus  on  its 
effectiveness in implementing the MDG strategy.
